Award.AwardTitle: SG: Distinguishing between core and transient species: new insights into the determinants of species richness
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how and why biodiversity varies across the globe is a long-standing focus of ecology and is a fundamental concern of many conservation efforts. However, simply counting the number of species in an area may not give an accurate representation of biodiversity because many of the species observed in an area do not occur there regularly. By analyzing data collected over the past forty years by volunteer birders at almost 500 locations across North America, it was found that most bird species fall into one of two categories: core species that are observed almost every year at a site, and transient species that are observed only rarely. The number of core bird species was most strongly related to local climate and vegetation, whereas the number of transient bird species was greatest in regions with a diversity of habitats, independent of climate. This project will assess the generality of this distinction between core and transient species, and the importance of that distinction for understanding patterns in species diversity across a broad range of taxonomic groups and ecosystems including birds, mammals, butterflies, plants, fish, plankton, and intertidal invertebrates.

Results from this research will have implications for both basic and applied understanding of the determinants of biodiversity, and for how ecological communities will respond to climate and land use change. Research training and career mentoring will be provided for one graduate student. In conjunction with the University of North Carolina's Center for Mathematics and Science Education and the Pre-College Program, public outreach activities will be developed that engage middle school students, including a large proportion from underrepresented groups. The Pre-College Program is an inquiry-based program of enrichment and encouragement in science and mathematics for women and minorities underrepresented in scientific and mathematical careers. One product of this outreach will be an interpretive display exhibited at the North Carolina Botanical Garden. The researchers will also provide structured workshops to improve the computational and data management skills of scientists of all levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project was to establish general principles in ecology through the synthesis of existing datasets that monitor the composition and diversity of ecological communities over time. From the published literature, online data catalogs, and Long-Term Ecological Research sites we compiled data on over 19,000 assemblages of birds, butterflies, plants, plankton, fish, mammals, mollusks, and aquatic invertebrates. We found that transient species—species that are found only intermittently at a site—make up a large fraction of the biodiversity of a location, regardless of taxonomic group or ecosystem. This is important because biodiversity is frequently measured based on the number of species encountered. If a large fraction of the species encountered are not regularly interacting members of the community, then such measures may misrepresent the true biodiversity present.

We showed that analyzing community data with and without the transient species included leads to very different perspectives on the species abundance distribution (the relative abundance of common and rare species), the species-area relationship (the rate at which diversity increases as larger areas are considered), temporal turnover (the degree to which community composition changes over time), and the environmental drivers that best explain biodiversity. We also identified ways to compare community patterns between taxonomic groups—e.g.  birds versus plankton—that were sampled at very different spatial scales. Finally, we find that for many species, a measure of transience, i.e. what percent of the time a species occurs at a site, may be a better indicator of how that species interacts with other competing species at that site and with the environment than traditionally used measures of density or abundance. These results are summarized in one published research paper, one published data paper, and two research papers that will soon be submitted for publication.

Over the course of this project support was provided for two PhD students and two undergraduates who received training in the best practices of data management, software development, and version control in addition to traditional advising on ecology and data analysis. We held two Software Carpentry workshops, one at Utah State University and one at the University of North Carolina, that provided training to 64 students and postdocs in use of the Unix shell, an introduction to R programming, databases, and version control.

Finally, as part of our Broader Impacts, we trained over 60 environmental educators and 50 middle school students (at Durham's Duke School) in a citizen science project called "Caterpillars Count!", showing them how to monitor the seasonal variability in foliage arthropods like caterpillars, spiders, and beetles. We developed lesson plans and learning activities that educators can use with their students or visitors, magnifying our impact in the long run.
